M.G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to M.G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the claims arise under Massachusetts landlord-tenant law.

M.G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to M.G.L. c. 223, § 1, because the property that is the subject of this Complaint is located in Cambridge, Massachusetts.

M.G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Pursuant to M.G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential lease in Massachusetts includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment, which guarantees that the tenant is entitled to use and enjoy the rented premises without substantial interference by the landlord.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 100 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial interference with a tenant’s ability to use and enjoy their rental premises violates M.G.L. c. 186, § 14.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 100 (1.support_reasoning: The court expressly interprets and applies M.G.L. c. 186, § 14’s “quiet enjoyment” language to a situation where recurrent flooding substantially interfered with the tenant’s ability to live in the apartment. It holds that such interference with quiet enjoyment—here, repeated unsanitary flooding—falls within § 14 and makes the landlord liable, thereby recognizing that serious interference with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises violates c. 186, § 14.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 100 (1.relevant_excerpt: “Section 14 belongs to a body of statutes establishing tenants’ remedies against landlords who fail to provide safe and sanitary housing… The common law background of § 14 also suggests that malicious intent is not a condition of liability. The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14.”

*Davis v. Jones*, 532 N.E.2d 299, 300 (M.proposition: Massachusetts courts have held that substantial interference with a tenant’s ability to use and enjoy their rental premises violates M.G.L. c. 186, § 14.

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 851.proposition: Defendant’s failure to mitigate the disruption caused by the construction amounts to a clear breach of the statutory covenant.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 851.support_reasoning: The case concerns whether a violation of the lead paint statute, without more, constitutes a breach of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment, and it holds that at least negligent conduct with notice is required. It does not discuss construction activity, disruption from construction, or a landlord’s duty to mitigate such disruption. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that failure to mitigate construction-related disruption is a clear breach of the statutory covenant.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 851.relevant_excerpt: “Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord and violation of the lead paint statute alone is not sufficient to prove such negligence. Stated differently, to obtain relief under § 14 for a claim of lead paint poisoning it must be demonstrated that the landlord had notice of or reason to know of the presence of lead and failed to take appropriate corrective measures.”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994) (nominal remedies inadequate where substantial interference exists)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Defendant’s offer of a $100 rent reduction is not an adequate remedy for the ongoing and significant interference Plaintiff has experienced.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion recognizes that serious, ongoing interference with tenants’ use of common areas can breach the covenant of quiet enjoyment and warrant injunctive relief and statutory damages, but it does not discuss or evaluate the adequacy of any monetary offer or ‘nominal’ compensation as a remedy. There is no mention of a landlord offering a small rent reduction or the court declaring such a remedy inadequate. Thus, while the case supports that substantial interference is actionable and can justify more than nominal relief, it does not specifically stand for the proposition that a $100 rent reduction (or any nominal sum) is an inadequate remedy.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “If the defendant has failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.… If the defendant has taken no action or inadequate action, despite covenanting that the plaintiffs’ right to quiet enjoyment shall not be interfered with, then the plaintiffs will be entitled to judgment, appropriate injunctive relief, costs and reasonable attorney’s fees.”
